Comments_List: literature studies, critical reading, postcolonial discourse

The seminar offered an introduction to the major figures, movements, and concepts in postcolonial theory through critical engagement with its literature. 

The course also allowed us to consider broader questions over the course of the semester-- how to read 'theory', what we might expect from it, and what it means to theorize the postcolonial as well as the literary.
Not sure that I developed any real skills; gained some insight into the question of essentialism. Definitely got a lot of feedback.

I walked away with a review of the Postcolonial theory I had previously read and having been exposed to some new texts. I also believe this course may have opened a new pathway for my own future research.

Strenght: professor mastered the material.
Weakness: He didn't dedicate enough time to lecture us about his views on the materials.

I felt the syllabus was well-structured and I really appreciated the opportunity for student presentations, which both expanded our grasp on certain topics while providing insight into the diverse interests of our classmates. 

A weakness would be that class discussion occasionally felt unproductive and/or misguided.
I think the course would be better if it were more focused and if we spent longer on each text. Also, we should have done more literature.

This course was a good introduction to Postcolonial Theory for someone who has never seen any of the authors on the syllabus. I had previously read some of the authors on the syllabus, which left me wanting more from class discussions than reviewing the content of each theoretical text. I would have liked to walk away from this course with a stronger sense of where Postcolonial Theory is today and where it might be in the future.

The presentations and final papers, however, provided a nice opportunity to make the class personal to one's own interests.
Yes-- the course is foundational for anyone in French/Francophone studies or AFAM.
It would depend on the student.
